awd_titl_txt: Crystallographic Gems to Link Materials' Properties: Stannides, Germanides, and Antimonides
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

The search for magnetic and thermoelectric materials with desired properties relies on the discovery of new metal-based compounds, and also requires that the materials can be grown as high quality single crystals. The research strategy of this project, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, is motivated by magnetocalorics for refrigeration, thermoelectrics for converting wasted heat to electricity, and magnetic materials for next generation quantum computing. This project provides training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in a multidisciplinary environment. They gain insights into the design of novel materials. The partnership between the research group and the scientific community fosters continued enhancement in science learning. The principle investigator's group also works with a high school team of students and industrial partners as part of the "Young Women in Science" group and "Nanoexplorers", pursuing materials science projects. Additionally, the Chan group performs hands-on materials science-related demonstrations for the general public.


Technical Abstract

Discovering new metal-based compounds and linking their chemical structures to magnetic, electrical, and thermal properties for energy applications is the goal of this research, which is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research. The growth of large single crystals is necessary to unequivocally determine the material's innate properties. With this award, the principle investigator studies several classes of materials containing lanthanide, mid-transition metals, and Group 14-15 elements. The motivation for this effort is to correlate the structural details to predict physical properties. The efforts focus on growing high quality single crystals of the Tb117Fe52Ge112 (Ln = Gd, Dy) and Ln30Ru4Sn31 structure types, which allows the study of structural complexity, complex magnetism, and low lattice thermal conductivity. In addition to studying structural phase stability of stannides and germanides, atomic displacement parameters are correlated with electrical resistivity as a testbed for predicting electrical properties of materials. Inspired by the emergence of spin glass and itinerant magnetism in Pr2Fe4Sb5, the magnetic and electrical properties of Ln2Fe4-xMxSb5 (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Sm; M = Mn, Co, Zn) are also investigated. Compounds of this structure type are of particular interest because of the Fe-triangular subunits coupled with Sb-square nets, two features found in several highly correlated systems. Students involved in the proposed project will also have the opportunity to work with collaborators at other institutions and national laboratories. The principle investigator's entire research group is involved in mentoring students at different levels, including undergraduates throughout the academic year and high school students in the summer.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Results from Prior NSF Support PI Julia Chan, DMR1700030/DMR-2131858/ DMR2209804, “Crystallographic Gems to Link Materials’ Properties: Stannides, Germanides, and Antimonides” (Amount: $490,200 – 9/1/17-8/31/23; grant number changed due to move to Baylor University).

Intellectual Merit: The goal of this proposal is to grow high quality single crystals of compounds adopting the Ce2Fe4Sb5 and Y3Rh4Sn13 structure types. A highlight of this project is also the discovery of a new class of germanides and stannides, which has the potential for optimization and chemical tuning of rich physical phenomena. During this period, students focused on optimizing reaction profiles to yield the most suitable single crystals to study the role of local crystallographic environment on the electrical and magnetic properties of several classes of new materials. We also built a furnace enabling the in-situ X-ray diffraction studies at Argonne National Laboratory Advanced Photon Source. Since 2018, the group published 48 peer-reviewed manuscripts and 5 recently submitted and 6 with undergraduate co-authors.

We have written several review articles to promote the status of the field. A highlight is “Casting a Wider Net: Rational Synthesis Design of Low-Dimensional Bulk Materials” (Acc. Chem. Res. 2018, 51, 12−20). In this article, we focused on low-dimensional solids, which are highly anisotropic by nature and show promise in new quantum materials leading to exotic physical properties not realized in three-dimensional materials. We can extend our synthetic strategy of the flux-growth method to designing single crystalline low-dimensional materials in bulk. It is important to consider the discovery of new layered intergrowth compounds may be possible by using structural subunits as building blocks. While low dimensional compounds are of current interest due to the physical properties not observed in 3D phases, we were motivated to consider compounds that might also exhibit anisotropic behavior in bulk systems to study correlations. We discovered a new homologous series, An+1BnX3n+1 (A = Lanthanide, B = Co, X=Group 14 elements), which was shown to be robust for chemical tuning of quantum intermetallic compounds. As part of our efforts to study lanthanides with valence stability, we also discovered a new kagome metal Yb0.5Co3Ge3 and find a temperature-dependent kink in the resistivity. Further, our low temperature structure determination shows a lowering of symmetry due to the discovery of charge density waves. All the discovery would not be possible without single crystal growth and characterization by in-house single and powder X-ray and synchrotron X-ray methods.

Broader Impacts: The grant supported 6-8 graduate students (50% URMs) at any given time, 7 undergraduate students (30% URMs), and three high school students (two Hispanic Americans, one who are both pursuing graduate studies in Physics and Computer Science) and several visiting post-bachelor students. Per COVID, we were still able to perform experiments collaboratively. The PI also had the opportunity to advise two postdoctoral associates over the last several years and all have secured positions. I am also pleased to see former students in my group employed at national labs (Los Alamos, Sandia), industry, or academic institutions making an impact in their community. They are successful and one of my former PhD students serves on the Board of Director for NOBCChE and was named Black Engineer of the year (2022). With courses taught in the classroom, the PI developed modules to teach symmetry elements which have been adapted to future outreach activities. We have performed experiments at the Waco farmer’s market and organized hands-on workshop at Baylor Mayborn Museum and K-12 schools, and we expect the relationships with established infrastructure will enable broadened activities. The current group consists of seven PhD students (including three URMs) and an undergraduate (also URM) and we look forward to disseminating our new modules to surrounding PUIs in Texas and Oklahoma.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2023
Modified by: Julia Y Chan

    Chem. Mater., 2021, 33, 7657
